Caroline is 37 years old and widowed with two children aged eight and 17.  She runs a salon to earn a living.  Besides this, she sells clothes in order to generate more income.  Caroline has employed two people to assist her in her business. Being a widowed lady with two children in school, she has worked hard to educate her children, thanks to Faulu Kenya for financial support.

Caroline hopes to open other outlets of her business in the future.  She has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy clothes to sell and to renovate her salon.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell and to renovate her salon

loans.name: Babita

texts.en:
In Nepal, large supermarkets are rare. Instead, most items can be found in the small, densely packed pasals that line the streets of every city and village. Piled high with utensils, paper goods, and anything else one would need, these stores are your one-stop shop in Nepal. Although usually packed into a space no larger than 100 square feet, these stores carry a sizeable and diverse inventory.  

With the help of a Kiva loan, pasal owners are able to keep inventory up and their customers happy. Competition is fierce, but with extra capital and a bit of creativity, the opportunity for profit is there.

Babita is 33 years-old. She is married and has one child, age 4.  

In 2002, she established her kitchen utensil store business. Working seven days a week and 14 hours a day, she supports her family.  

She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW and used it to increase the inventory of her store.  

In the future, Babita plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more kitchen utensils to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Dzame

texts.en:
Dzame is a married woman with seven children; five attend school while two have graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighboring community members. Dzame dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar, maize flour and paraffin. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar, maize flour and also paraffin.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie is 34 years old and lives in Mitazan, Aloaran, Misamis Occidental. She is single.

To earn a living, Rosie has a business sell clothings. She earns about PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. Rosie has requested a loan of 14,900 to purchase more clothes to sell.

Rosie has been a member of PMPC for five years.  In the future, Rosie would like to have a big store of boutique.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 24 years old, married, and lives with his wife and a family member who works. 

Since 2009 Mohammad has owned a kiosk, making tea, hot drinks, and cold beverages. He got this work from his grandfather and he has sufficient experience. He has a good reputation and his kiosk is situated in a crowded area where there are a lot of customers passing by. 

He is requesting a $2400 loan in order to buy a new kiosk and gas bottles. He aims to make more money to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: In order to buy a new kiosk and gas bottles.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
James has been operating his butchery shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last five years.  He is 39 years old, married to Wanjiru, and they have three school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET through existing clients and this is his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy more meat to sell in his butchery.

In future, James hopes to expand his business and improve his living standards.

loans.use: Buy more meat to sell.

loans.name: Abadahemuka/shr Group

texts.fr:
Philippe fait partie du groupe Abadahemuka/Shr. Le nom du groupe signifie «les fideles». Il a 34 ans et il est marié avec 6 enfants de 2 à 10 ans, dont 4 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est de 5 ans de primaire.

Philippe est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire les semences sélectionnée. Dans les prochaines années, Philippe voudrait être le distributeur du riz dans sa région. Avec les profits, il prévoit d’éduquer et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en:
Philip is part of the Abadahemuka/Shr group. The group's name means "the faithful".

He is 34 years old and is married with six children aged two to ten years, including four who attend school. His own schooling has been five years of primary school.

Philippe is a rice farmer. It is his first loan cycle with ACB. He will use his credit to buy fertilizer for his rice farming activity.

His strategy for growing his business is to use selected seeds. In coming years, Philippe would like to become the rice distributor for the region. With his profits, he plans to look after his children's care and education needs.

loans.use: buy fertilizer for his rice farming activity.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a 50-year-old widowed woman with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her business is selling first-hand clothes. She faces the challenge of customers not paying on time and inadequate capital to meet her customers' different preferences. Her personal goals are to build a permanent house and to educate her children. Her desire is to expand her business into a shopping mall. Stella needs money to buy new clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell.

loans.name: Tatenda Group

texts.en:
Shillah is a 34-year-old lady and she is a single mother with 3 children aged 14, 12 and 5 years old. Two of the children are going to school. She does not have other dependants. 

She is a general dealer who sells groceries and clothing at Save Business Centre. She has been in business for seven years now and is doing well. She has 3 employees who work for her. She does not face any challenge other than of lack of capital. In the next 5 years she wants to acquire another business stand so that she wll have two business shops at Save. With the profits from the laon she will be able to pay fees for her siblings.

loans.use: to buy groceries for restocking.

loans.name: Subhon

texts.ru: Субхон открыл собственную аптеку. В этой области он семь лет. Кредит берет для расширения своей деятельности.
texts.en: Subhon operates his own pharmacy. He has been running his business for the last seven years and needs this loan to expand it.

loans.use: to purchase drugs

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is separated has two children. Arlene has a shop that sells clothing & beauty products from NATASHA and AVON. She has had this business for three years. She is requesting a loan of PHP 11,000 to buy more stock from NATASHA and AVON.

Arlene has been a member of HSPFI since 2010, and hopes to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy stocks from NATASHA and AVON

loans.name: Philip

texts.en: Phillip, 35 years old, is a single man. He has two children, aged five and eleven years. He has been selling cakes and doughnuts for the last two years. His primary customers are residents. His business challenges are insufficient funds and transportation problems while delivering his items. He will use the requested loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cakes and doughnuts. In the future, Phillip wants to own a bakery shop.

loans.use: to buy more cakes and doughnuts to sell

loans.name: Egla

texts.en: Egla is a married woman. She has two children with ages ranging between 8 and 15 years old. She describes herself to be polite. She operates a retail store where she sells maize. She has been involved in this business for four years. In addition, she also sells tea to add her income. Her business is located within her home area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high price of maize. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase more maize. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler within five years. In the next five future, she hopes she will run another maize store in a neighboring town.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 41 years old and a businessman. He is married to Catherine, a farmer. They are blessed with three children aged 12, eight and three years respectively. He has been in the livestock trading business for the past five years with the monthly income of KES 10,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan term with KADET LTD after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. James will use the loan to buy more livestock for trading. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. His hope and dream is to buy a pick-up for transporting his livestock to different markets.

loans.use: To buy more livestock for trading.

loans.name: Nak's Group

texts.en:
A resident from the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Nak is 35 years old and has two children who are in school. She provides for her household via rice cropping, which is her single source of income and one that she has occupied for 15 years. She has been involved in her current business for ages and it has given her a return of about 45,000 KHR per day. 

Now, she has a shortage of working capital to support her business. Therefore, she has formed a group of two to get a new loan. As the group leader, Nak will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop. She hopes to make more crops from her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop.

loans.name: Wilfrid Francis Eric

texts.fr: Marié à une commerçante  du nom de Wilfrid Francis Eric et père de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et deux à sa charge, Wilfrid Francis Eric est âgé de 47 ans. Wilfrid Francis Eric vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Wilfrid Francis Eric subvient ensemble avec sa femme aux divers besoins du ménage. Wilfrid Francis Eric a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Pour assurer ses diverses charges, Wilfrid Francis Eric vend des boissons à son domicile depuis dix ans et dispose d'un cafétéria et une structure de lavage qu'il gère de façon secondaire. Cette activité lui permet de contribuer aux diverses charges de sa famille. Wilfrid Francis Eric s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Wilfrid Francis Eric sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Le premier crédit a été bien remboursé.

loans.use: Acheter des boissons.

loans.name: Abunda

texts.en:
Abundia is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with two children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. 

Abundia dreams that one day, She will be able to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand and diversify my business

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married with seven children. Her husband is unemployed and is making very little money from day-labor. The visible needs of her children are Regina's motivation. In view of her determination and training in marketing techniques, credit management, and available support from group and center members, she hopes to succeed.

Given a loan of $75, Regina plans to buy and retail different varieties of vegetables to her immediate community. She plans to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Sale of vegetables and plastic containers

loans.name: Adelia

texts.en:
Adelia S. is married and has two children. Her husband's name is Pablino Gonzalez and he's 31 years old. Their children are minors and currently attend one of the city's public schools. The family lives in a rented house; the couple's fondest dream is to buy their own home, a goal towards which they are currently working.

Adelia is a trained seamstress and she specializes in curtains. She worked several years for a well known curtain manufacturer in the city. Because her salary wasn't enough to cover basic home expenses, she decided to start her own curtain business from home. She was soon joined by her husband and together they've developed a large clientele based on the high quality of their work.

Adelia is requesting a loan of US $200 to purchase fabric in order to accommodate a large order from one of her clients

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Adelia S. es casada y tiene 2 hijos, su marido se llama Pablino González y tiene 31 años. Sus hijos son menores de edad y actualmente están estudiando en una escuela pública de la ciudad. Ellos viven todos juntos en una casa alquilada; el mayor sueño de la pareja es poder adquirir su casa propia, para lo cual están trabajando. Adelia es confeccionista y su especialidad son las cortinas, ella trabajo varios años en una cortinería muy reconocida de la ciudad; como la remuneración que percibía no alcanzaba para cubrir los gastos de la casa, ella decidió trabajar de forma independiente desde su casa junto con su marido que también se dedica a la confección; pronto adquirieron una buena cantidad de clientes ya que sus trabajos son de muy buena calidad. Adelia solicita un crédito de $ 200 que los invertirá en la compra de telas, ya que ha recibido un pedido grande de cortinas de uno de sus clientes.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos is 24 years old and he is single. He opened his own business more than five years ago. Previously, he was working with his father from whom he learned the trade. Carlos is a self-sacrificing young man, who goes to university at night; he is studying the third year of Accounting, thanks to his work and effort. He fixes electronic articles like TV sets, computers, radios, etc. His business is well located and he already has a good clientele, he also does home repairs to generate a bigger income. He needs the loan to buy a tester to improve his service and cover to the demand of the clients.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Carlos tiene 24 años de edad, es soltero, hace más de cinco años que habilitó su propio negocio anteriormente estuvo trabajando con su padre de quien aprendió el oficio. Carlos es un joven muy sacrificado, quien a la noche estudia en la facultad, está cursando el tercer año de la carrera de Ciencias Contables, gracias a su trabajo y esfuerzo. El se dedica a componer artículos electrónicos como televisores, computadoras, radios, etc. Su local está bien ubicado y tiene clientela formada, también realiza trabajos a domicilio para generar más ingresos. Necesita el crédito para la compra de un tester para mejorar su servicio y satisfacer la demanda de los clientes.

loans.use: Buy tools and a tester

loans.name: Ngwa Christina

texts.en:
Christina is an orphan and the mother of five children. The death of her twin babies is something she will never be able to forget.

As a hardworking woman, she has a small bench in front of her house where she sells food and other basic items. With a loan of $100 (40,000 FCFA), she plans to invest in the business she already runs.

The profit will enable her to pay school fees for her children and buy food for the family. She believes the business will succeed as her small store is known in her residential area.

She plans to repay the loan in 12 -15 months, with the first installment on the day the loan is received.

loans.use: To purchase rice, palm oil, magi, groundnuts and soap

loans.name: Nancy's Group

texts.es:
Delia is 52 years old and has seven children, Nancy is 35 years old and has one daughter, and Nelly is 38 years old and has three children. What they all have in common is their membership to “Dos Mil” (Two Thousand) Communal Bank. The tree of them mention that, in their Communal Bank, they learned to socialize, to better serve their customers and to save. They have been members of the Communal Bank for 3, 6 and 3 years respectively, and it’s during this time that they’ve been able to save. With her savings, Nancy was able to buy a TV, a fridge and a stereo, while Delia acquired a freezer for her business.

They run different businesses. In Nancy’s case, she has a small grocery store. She decided to start this business because there were no stores on her street.

Delia, on her part, sells ice creams that she elaborates herself. She sells them as a peddler, in front of the San Francisco de Asis church, in the downtown area of the city.

Finally, Nelly elaborates typical regional breads, such as “chapla”, sells them in the area and also ships them to a different province. She started in the business when she was 14 years old, as apprentice at different bakeries. When she was 25 years old, she managed to get her own oven.

In the future, they would like to see their businesses grow, stock them and be able to elaborate a wider variety of breads. They are requesting loans for 400, 1000 and 600 soles respectively, to be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, milk, noodles, oil, flour, dyes, fruits and additives.

Delia, Nancy and Nelly dream of their children becoming professionals, of buying a stretch of land to build a house, and of buying a car for a son to work.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Delia tiene 52 años y 7 hijos, Nancy tiene 35 años y 1 hija, y Nelly tiene 38 años y 3 hijos. Lo que ellas tienen en común es que son socias del Banco Comunal Dos Mil y las tres mencionan que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a socializarse, cómo atender al cliente, y a ahorrar. Son socias del Banco Comunal desde hace 3, 6 y 3 años respectivamente y es en todo este tiempo que han logrado ahorrar. Con los ahorros que logró reunir, Nancy pudo comprar su televisor, refrigeradora y un equipo de música, mientras que Delia compró una congeladora para su negocio.

Los negocios de ellas son diferentes. En el caso de Nancy, tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes. Ella decidió iniciar este negocio porque no había tiendas en su cuadra.

Por otro lado, Delia vende helados que son elaborados por ella misma; sus ventas las hace en forma ambulante, frente a la Iglesia San Francisco de Asís, en el centro de la ciudad.

Finalmente, Nelly elabora panes típicos de la región como la “chapla” y los vende a las tiendas de la zona y también manda a otra provincia. Ella se inició en este negocio a los 14 años, como ayudante en diferentes hornos y, posteriormente, a los 25 años logró hacer su propio horno.

En el futuro ellas quisieran que sus negocios crezcan, surtir su negocio y poder elaborar mayor variedad de panes. Los préstamos que ellas necesitan son de 400, 1000 y 600 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos, aceite, harina, colorantes, frutas y estabilizadores.

Los sueños de Delia, Nancy y Nelly son que sus hijos sean profesionales, comprar su terreno y construir su casa, y un carro para que pueda trabajar su hijo.

loans.use: They are requesting loans for 400, 1000 and 600 soles respectively, to be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, milk, noodles, oil, flour, dyes, fruits and additives.

loans.name: Yuli Magali's Group

texts.en:
Silvia, Karina, and Yuli have been members of the community bank Glorioso for 3, 2, and 12 years respectively. In that time they have learned how to save, how to run their business, and how to continue to develop their business. In addition they have learned about self-esteem and respect. They feel like their bank is a family where they can relax and share their problems.

Silvia is 55 years old and has five children. She has owned a bakery for the past 15 years. Now she has established clients who always buy from her every day. Karina is 20 years old and owns a small café. She also goes to school where she studies accounting. Yuli is 32 and has one son. She is a founding member of her community bank. Yuli sells clothing and cosmetics to her friends, family, and other associates at the bank.

Silvia, Karina, and Yuli need loans of 800 soles, 1000 soles, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying products for their businesses, such as flour, sugar, eggs, and more cosmetics.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving and each member has an interest-earning savings account. Silvia, Karina, and Yuli are saving for the education of their children, for an upcoming marriage, and to open a restaurant. Each woman has her own dream. Silvia hopes for a better life for her children. Karina dreams of finishing her degree and getting married. Yuli hopes to one day open a restaurant and one day own a chain of restaurants across all of Peru.

loans.use: Silvia, Karina and Yuli need loans of 800 soles, 1000 soles, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying products for their businesses, such as flour, sugar, eggs, and more cosmetics.

loans.name: Buziika Central C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Tatia M.. She is currently in the business of shoe selling and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Tatia is 46 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 8 children ranging from age 10 to 31 and her children go to school. Each week, Tatia makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add capital to the business. Tatia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Tatia is joined in her small group by Rose N., Sarah N., Daizy N., and Esther A.. Rose N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase stock. Sarah N. is currently operating a business selling coffee and wants a loan to boost business. Daizy N. operates a business selling milk and wants to add more capital to the business. Esther A. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To expand shoe business and make more profits

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.es:
Eduardo is a hard-working young man who has helped strengthen the family business over many years. Now he has decided to set off on his own by buying some animals that he will raise for a short period of time in order to sell at his city's large stock shows. He wants to become the best rancher which is why he requests a loan with which he will increase the number of animals that he is able to raise.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Eduardo, es un joven trabajador que luego de haber contribuido con la consolidación del negocio familiar por mucho tiempo, ha decidido emprender su camino de comercialización con la compra de algunos animales a los que acogerá por un corto período a fin de ofertarlos en las grandes ferias ganaderas de su ciudad.Su deseo de convertirse en el mejor criador lo conducen a solicitar un préstamo para incrementar el número de animales que alberga.

loans.use: To purchase more animals

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a fifty-nine-year old widowed mother of five children and eight grandchildren. She sells maize and plantains in Accra’s busy Agblogbloshie market. She purchases her products through suppliers and then sells them to local hotels, restaurants, and streetside vendors in Accra.

She will use the loan to expand her inventory of maize and plantains and guard against price hikes. She hopes to use the proceeds of her increased sales to build a house some day.

Comfort is a member of the "Awurade Kae Me" (Remember Me, God) lending group. The lending group uses a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To buy more maize and plantains

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is married and she has three children. Two of her children are in school. She buys in bulk foodstuffs like plantain, maize and avocado pear from the nearby villages and towns and sells them to clients in the big towns and cities for more income. She wants to use her loan to buy more foodstuffs to avoid price hikes in the produce. She is a member of the group called Paul Amantem. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Diana is in the photo with two of her children.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like plantain, maize and avocado pear

loans.name: Khean

texts.en:
Mrs. Khean K., 40, and her husband, Mr. Saroeun Meach, 47, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1989 and have four children--two sons and two daughters. One of the children weaves silk at home, and the other three are in school.

Mrs. Khean has been a silk weaver for over 10 years. This is a skill that she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Saroeun has been a taxi driver for over 10 years. The couple is in the process of building their new house. They need money to buy lattices to make the walls of the house.

Mrs. Khean is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase lattices to use to make the walls of their house.

loans.use: To purchase lattices to use to make the walls of the house that she is building.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.es:
Mrs. Ofelia is a 38-year-old single mother, who finished junior high. She has a 21-year-old daughter and a 4-year-old boy. They all live in Jr. Incas nº 58 of the Yunguyo Province. Ofelia sells cups, thermos jugs, small radios, which she sells wholesale. The products were brought from the city of Tacna, La Paz Bolivia. She decided to have her own store by suggestion of some friends at the same Yunguyo. She has the support of her daughter; but the business needed a little more capital, this is when she joined the Wiñay Marca Communal Bank. She first started with a loan of $105, that she used to buy small TV sets and radios. With this new loan of $900, which will be repaid over a period of 4 months, she will buy TV sets, mini components and Dvds. She is happy because she increased her revenue. Her big dream is to have a big appliance store, she wants to support her children in their studies, and later buy a car.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ofelia; madre soltera, tiene 38 años de edad, culmino sus estudios secundarios, tiene una hija de 21 años de edad y otro de 04 años quienes viven en el Jr. Los incas nº 58 del Distrito y Provincia de Yunguyo. Ofelia se dedica al comercio de tazas, termos, radios pequeñas, que dejaba por mayor los cuales eran traídos de la ciudad de Tacna, La Paz Bolivia, por sugerencia de algunas amigas tomo la decisión de tener un puesto propio, en el mismo Yunguyo, para lo cual contaba con el apoyo de su hija; pero el negocio requería un poco mas de capital, es donde logro integrar al Banco Comunal Wiñay Marca para lo cual inicio con un préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero con que compro pequeños televisores y radios. Con este crédito de S/. 2,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará televisores, mini componentes y DvDs. Ella vive contenta por que mejoro su ingreso. su gran anhelo es tener una gran tienda de artefactos, apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios, posterior mente adquirir un carro.

loans.use: Buy television sets, dvd players, etc.

loans.name: Rajabgul

texts.ru:
Rajabgul S. lives in the Fayzabad region. She lives together with her large family. Rajabgul is married and has 8 children. Her husband is not able to support such a large family on his own and Rajabgul needs to work hard in order to help support her family.

Rajabgul sells products at the Miskinobod market. She has decided to take out an 18 month loan in order to increase her inventory for the fall season. The loan will help her to increase her product selection and to attract new customers. As a result, her business will grow.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Сайфиддинова Раджабгуль жительница района Файзабад. Живет вместе со своей большой семьей.Замужем и имеет восьмерых детей. Прокормить такую большую семью одному мужу не под силу , поэтому Раджабгуль приходится много работать , чтобы помочь семье. Зангимается торговлей на рынке Мискинобода. Решила к осеннему сезону увеличить товарооборот путем получения кредита сроком на 18 месяцев. Это поможет увеличить ассортимент товара и привлечь новых клиентов . Таким образом ее бизнес начнет развиваться.

loans.use: Increase product assortment

loans.name: Maritza Maxima

texts.es:
Maritza Q. vive en la zona de villa Cooperativa de la ciudad de El Alto con sus padres e hijos de 18, 12 y 9 respectivamente los cuales estudian en una escuela fiscal de la zona. No tiene casa propia.
 
Tiene un puesto frente a un colegio de la zona donde vende dulces por las mañanas y por las tardes tiene un trabajo en la misma zona donde confecciona chamarras.

El crédito lo destinara  como capital de trabajo. 
 
Es su segundo  crédito con Impro, dado que ambas ocupaciones le reportan beneficios, es una persona apta para recibir un crédito.
texts.en:
Maritza Q. lives in the area of Villa Cooperativa in the city of El Alto with her parents and children of 18, 12, and 9 years of age, respectively. They study in the local school. She does not have her own house.

She has a stand in front of a high school in the area where she sells sweets in the mornings and, in the afternoons, she has a job working in the same area where she makes jackets.

The loan will be allocated as capital for her work.

This is her second loan with Impro, given that both jobs give her profits, she is a person likely to receive a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Lyiomal

texts.fr: Lyiomal P. tient depuis 2 ans un magasin de dépôt fanmilk, à Lomé la capitale togolaise. Agé de 32 ans, Lyiomal est marié et père de 2 enfants dont le premier est sur les bancs de l’école. Ce commerce étant sa seule source de revenu, il espère avec ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son magasin pour accroître ses ventes et par là, ses gains, pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
For two years, Lyiomal P. has been running a Fan Milk (dairy retailer) shop in Lomé, the capital of Togo. He's 32 years old, married, and the father of 2 children, out of which the first one goes to school. This business being is only source of revenues, he hopes to use this loan to bolster his stock and to increase his sales, in order to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his stock

loans.name: Ukeria

texts.en: Ukeria is a pensioner after retiring from teaching primary school. She has seven children and four grandchildren, and she is 54 years old and married. Ukeria is a proud woman who is very happy with the financial assistance she is receiving from LAPO Microfinance. Ukeria is pictured with a daughter and grandson. Ukeria sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs in her shop. Ukeria is requesting a loan of 100,000 N to purchase more provisions, drinks and juice to sell. She is grateful to Kiva lenders and to LAPO Microfinance for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, provisions and juice to sell

loans.name: Sithach

texts.en:
Sithach Y., 39, is a widow with three children; two sons and one daughter. Two of her children are garment factory workers and the other is an outside shutter worker. The family lives in a small village twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.
Sithach has been a grocery seller for one year. She wants to expand her business by purchasing more grocery items to add in her shop, but haslimited funds. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of US$300 to purchase more grocery items for resale and for her stock to increase output.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her stock.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Hong

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng T. năm nay 28  tuổi..Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007.   Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị đều đang kinh donh điện thoại di động. Do nhu cầu tiêu thụ điện  thoại di động và các dịch vụ của người dân ngày càng nâng cao nên công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đang tiến triển rất thuận lợi với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. 
Vòng vốn tới chị T. mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc kinh doanh điện thoại.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Hồng T., 28 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2007. Currently, she and her husband run a business selling cell phones. Due to the steadily rising consumer demand for mobile phones and related services, her business is thriving and now provides her family with an income of about 3,000,000 VND (183 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, Mrs. T. hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (550 USD) to invest in her cell phone business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cell phone business

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor provides the community with fresh food and other essential goods. The Esperanza Home Improvement team met with Victor, who asked for a loan to conduct modest repairs. Victor plans to install new doors and add windows to improve the customer experience.  He is an active member of the Bank of Hope and has successfully repaid several business loans.  

Please help us fund his renovations.  Thank you!

loans.use: House repair

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is a 34-year-old woman. She is divorced and the mother of 2 kids. She divorced after her husband refused to take responsibility for the children. Currently, the kids are in school. She lives with her kids in Shiashie, a suburb of Accra in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. Mary is an achiever and a resourceful mother who always wants to see smiles on the faces of her children. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. She trades in maize and cocoa drinks. She treks to the Volta Region and Brong Ahafo to purchase bulk stocks of maize from farmers and retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick enough stock to make enough profit to support her family.

With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk supplies of maize and to add groundnuts and millet to her stock, which she believes will enable her to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her kids in school. She belongs to a village bank called Honesty.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of maize and cocoa powder

loans.name: Marco Antonio

texts.es:
Marco tiene un punto de llamadas y de juegos en red, es soltero.
Su trabajo le ayuda a poder solventarse los gastos de alimentación y otros ya que es independiente.
Vive en la zona de Alto San Pedro de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus padres.
El crédito será destinado para capital de Inversión ( reparación y mantenimiento de tres computadoras)
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, las ganas de superarse le dan la oportunidad de accede a este crédito.
texts.en:
Marco owns a phone and internet gaming center, and is single. His work allows him to cover food and other costs, as he is independent. He lives in the Alto San Pedro area of the city of La Paz in his parents' house. The loan will be invested in capital (repair and maintenance of three computers). This is his first loan from Impro. His drive to overcome gave him the opportunity to access this credit.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in capital

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.es:
Luzmila es socia del Bancomunal Amigas Unidas.
Luzmila es casada tiene 42 años, tiene tres hijos de  23, 13 y 7 años, los dos últimos están en la escuela estatal.
Luzmila era vendedora ambulante por mucho tiempo, alquilo un puesto y se puso a vender fruta, pero no le rendía se le malograba mucho, ella vio que el vender condimentos tenia mas salida y le dejaba mas rentabilidad.
Luzmila necesita un crédito de 1200 soles para la compra de condimentos al por mayor, vinagre, sillao.queso. 
Desde que Luzmila esta en Finca a podido aumentar su mercadería, ha recibido, ha recibido orientación  para su negocio, ahora sabe cómo administrar mejor el negocio.  
El sueño de Luzmila es tener un puesto propio.
texts.en:
Luzmila is a member of Bancomunal Amigas Unidas. She is 42 years old, married, and has three children aged 23, 13, and 7. The youngest two children are in the state school. Luzmila was a street vendor for a long time and then she rented a booth and began to sell fruit, but the business did not profit and she ended up wasting a lot. She realized that there were more opportunities for her to sell condiments and it would be more profitable for her. Luzmila needs a loan of 1,200 soles (USD$400) to purchase vinegar, soy sauce and cheese at wholesale prices. Since Luzmila has been a part of FINCA she has been able to increase her stock, has received business advice, and now knows how to administrate her own business. Luzmila’s dream is to own her own booth.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase condiments at wholesale prices
